relics.name: Lucky Phantom
relics.description: This QA phantom has been with you for years and seems to bring good fortune.

effect.description: 50% chance to auto-pass machine QA questions

content.question: What is the correction factor for temperature and pressure called in TG-51?
content.explanation: kTP is the temperature-pressure correction factor in TG-51 that adjusts for the difference between calibration and measurement conditions.

content.title: Reference Material
content.text: You study important concepts in your textbook.

content.question: Which of the following imaging modalities uses ionizing radiation?
content.explanation: Computed Tomography (CT) uses X-rays, which are a form of ionizing radiation.

content.question: If a radioisotope has a half-life of 8 days, approximately what fraction of the original activity will remain after 24 days?
content.explanation: After 24 days (3 half-lives), the remaining activity is (1/2)³ = 1/8 of the original activity.

content.question: According to TG-142, what is the tolerance for photon beam flatness constancy during monthly QA?
content.explanation: According to TG-142, the tolerance for photon beam flatness constancy during monthly QA is ±2%.

content.question: According to TG-142, what is the tolerance for photon beam flatness constancy during monthly QA?
content.explanation: According to TG-142, the tolerance for photon beam flatness constancy during monthly QA is ±2%.

content.question: What is the main advantage of IMRT over 3D conformal radiotherapy?
options: Better dose conformity to the target
content.explanation: The main advantage of IMRT over 3D conformal radiotherapy is better dose conformity to the target volume, especially for complex shapes, allowing better sparing of adjacent normal tissues.

content.question: What is the main advantage of IMRT over 3D conformal radiotherapy?
options: Better dose conformity to the target
content.explanation: The main advantage of IMRT over 3D conformal radiotherapy is better dose conformity to the target volume, especially for complex shapes, allowing better sparing of adjacent normal tissues.

content.question: Which of the following imaging modalities uses ionizing radiation?
content.explanation: Computed Tomography (CT) uses X-rays, which are a form of ionizing radiation.

content.question: What is the frequency of full calibration required after a source exchange for an HDR unit?
options: Immediately before the first patient treatment
Within 24 hours before the first patient treatment
Within 7 days before the first patient treatment
Within 30 days before the first patient treatment
content.explanation: A full calibration of an HDR unit is required immediately before the first patient treatment following a source exchange.

content.question: According to NRC regulations, how soon must a medical event be reported to the NRC Operations Center?
content.explanation: According to NRC regulations, a medical event must be reported to the NRC Operations Center within 24 hours of discovery.

content.question: Which of the following is a potential disadvantage of using a non-coplanar beam arrangement?
content.explanation: Non-coplanar beam arrangements generally increase treatment time due to the need for couch rotations between fields, although they may provide dosimetric advantages in certain cases.

content.title: Rotation Evaluation
content.text: Your knowledge is being tested as part of your rotation evaluation.

questions.question: Which of the following is typically measured in monthly linac QA?
questions.explanation: Output constancy is a critical parameter checked during monthly QA to ensure the linac is delivering the expected dose.

questions.question: According to NRC regulations, how soon must a medical event be reported to the NRC Operations Center?
questions.explanation: According to NRC regulations, a medical event must be reported to the NRC Operations Center within 24 hours of discovery.

questions.question: What is the primary factor that determines induced activity in a linear accelerator during high-energy photon beam operation?
questions.explanation: Beam energy is the primary factor that determines photonuclear reactions leading to induced activity in a linear accelerator. Energies above 10 MV can produce photoneutrons that cause activation.

content.question: In inverse planning for IMRT, what is typically specified as part of the optimization objectives?
options: The number of monitor units per segment
Dose-volume constraints for targets and organs at risk
content.explanation: In inverse planning for IMRT, dose-volume constraints (or objectives) for targets and organs at risk are specified, and the treatment planning system optimizes the fluence patterns to meet these objectives.

content.title: Reference Material
content.text: You study important concepts in your textbook.

content.question: What is the tissue-phantom ratio (TPR) used for?
options: To convert percentage depth dose to different source-to-surface distances
To account for inverse square law effects in treatment planning
To measure the quality of the beam
To describe the dose at a point relative to the dose at a reference depth
content.explanation: The tissue-phantom ratio (TPR) describes the dose at a point in a phantom relative to the dose at a reference depth, with the same source-to-detector distance.

content.question: In inverse planning for IMRT, what is typically specified as part of the optimization objectives?
options: The number of monitor units per segment
Dose-volume constraints for targets and organs at risk
content.explanation: In inverse planning for IMRT, dose-volume constraints (or objectives) for targets and organs at risk are specified, and the treatment planning system optimizes the fluence patterns to meet these objectives.
